s.text: A Lincoln Town Car is waiting outside your door in the morning to take you to work.
Vanity Fair 's Graydon Carter might be there too, although he has transferred his main allegiance to a place called Patroon.
Si's favorite courtiers lead lives of jaw-dropping privilege.
She bills your candy bar, juice, and cigarettes (as well as her own candy bar, juice, and cigarettes) to the magazine ($15).

You've forgotten to return the video your kids watched yesterday, so you have a messenger take it back to Blockbuster.

To be fair, Si doesn't pay for all such treats.
To be fair, Si doesn't pay for all such treats.
Actually, paying $100,000 for face time with Princess Di may not have been a foolish investment for a magazine so dependent on peddling her image.
S.I. "Si" Newhouse Jr. and his younger brother, Donald, control Advance Publications, one of America's largest privately held companies.
